amazed.solver

Class SequentialSolver

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.util.concurrent.ForkJoinTask<V>
      • java.util.concurrent.RecursiveTask<java.util.List<java.lang.Integer>>
        • amazed.solver.SequentialSolver
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.util.concurrent.Future<java.util.List<java.lang.Integer>>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    ForkJoinSolver

    public class SequentialSolver
extends java.util.concurrent.RecursiveTask<java.util.List<java.lang.Integer>>
    SequentialSolver implements a solver for Maze objects using a single-thread depth-first search.

    Even though SequentialSolver is implemented as a RecursiveTask, it is purely sequential. Method compute returns a solution consisting of a list of node identifiers in the maze that lead from the start node to a goal.

    Depth-first search is implemented using a stack of frontier nodes — giving the nodes to be explored next in depth-first order. Visited nodes are added to a set visited. For each visited node, predecessor keeps track of the other node adjacent to the visited node that has been visited just before it. Method pathFromTo reconstructs a path by following the precedessor relation backwards.

    See Also:

    • Field Detail

      • maze

        protected Maze maze
        The maze being searched.

      • forkAfter

        protected int forkAfter
        Number of steps (nodes to be visited) before forking. This is set to 0 in SequentialSolver, which means no forking.

      • visited

        protected java.util.Set<java.lang.Integer> visited
        Set of identifiers of all nodes visited so far during the search.

      • predecessor

        protected java.util.Map<java.lang.Integer,java.lang.Integer> predecessor
        If (m -> n) is in precedessor, then the node with identifier n has been first visited from its neighbor node with identifier m during the search.

      • frontier

        protected java.util.Stack<java.lang.Integer> frontier
        The nodes in the maze to be visited next. Using a stack implements a search that goes depth first..

      • start

        protected int start
        The identifier of the node in the maze from where the search starts.

    • Method Detail

      • initStructures

        protected void initStructures()
        Initializes visited, predecessor, and frontier with empty data structures for sequential access.

      • compute

        public java.util.List<java.lang.Integer> compute()
        Searches for and returns the path, as a list of node identifiers, that goes from the start node to a goal node in the maze. If such a path cannot be found (because there are no goals, or all goals are unreacheable), the method returns null.
        Specified by:
        compute in class java.util.concurrent.RecursiveTask<java.util.List<java.lang.Integer>>
        Returns:
        the list of node identifiers from the start node to a goal node in the maze; null if such a path cannot be found

      • pathFromTo

        protected java.util.List<java.lang.Integer> pathFromTo(int from,
                                                       int to)
        Returns the connected path, as a list of node identifiers, that goes from node from to node to following the inverse of relation predecessor. If such a path cannot be reconstructed from predecessor, the method returns null.
        Parameters:
        from - the identifier of the initial node on the path
        to - the identifier of the final node on the path
        Returns:
        the list of node identifiers from from to to if such a path can be reconstructed from predecessor; null otherwise
